speaker: Teacher
text: So what was the word again for she in French? She.

speaker: Teacher
text: "Elle." [open 'e' sound] E-L-L-E. "Elle." [open 'e' sound] Good. So this final E, which isn't usually pronounced, with some important exceptions which we will see, most of the time gives us a feminine noun. And we see this E popping up for the feminine as in "elle," [open 'e' sound] as in the feminine word for a or one, "une." [pronounced N] As in the feminine ending that we saw, "-ette." Like in baguette, la baguette, la bicyclette. What was she can?

speaker: Teacher
text: Elle peut." [open 'e' sound] How would you say, "She can invite him? She can invite him?"

speaker: Teacher
text: Elle peut l'inviter." [open 'e' sound] She can invite him to the birthday party. She can invite him to the anniversary fête, non? The birthday party. So from the beginning. She can?

speaker: Teacher
text: So what was to the party?

speaker: Teacher
text: You're still thinking about the second bit, no?

speaker: Teacher
text: So leave that. Worry about that when you get there because whatever you work out about it now, you will have to hold onto it until you get there anyway. And that's very distracting. So when you realize you're thinking about something that's not now, leave it. To the party?

speaker: Teacher
text: She can invite him to the birthday party, or she can invite her to the birthday party. They both sound the same here, non?

speaker: Student
text: Elle peut l'inviter à la fête d'anniversaire.

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Elle peut l'inviter [open 'e' sound] à la fête d'anniversaire." Very good. He, the word for he is "il." This is spelled I-L, "il."

speaker: Teacher
text: Il veut." And what was the word for me?

speaker: Teacher
text: It's spelled M-E. Just M-E. The normal E with no accent written on it. So how do we pronounce that in French?

speaker: Teacher
text: Me." [schwa sound] Good. He wants to invite me.

speaker: Teacher
text: Il veut m'inviter." The mobile phone, the mobile phone. The mobile in French, well, it's the portable in French. "Le portable."

speaker: Teacher
text: At least in France. In, in other French-speaking countries, you will hear other words like cellulaire cellulaire, non? Or GSM. GSM. GSM in French. And in France, whilst people say portable for mobile, you will see mobile or mobile, uh, written around on adverts, et cetera. But people say portable.

speaker: Teacher
text: Il veut le portable." Very good. So portable ends in E, no, but it's not feminine. How would you say, "He wants it? He wants it"? And we mean the phone.

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. Il le veut. Do you remember the word for black? Like in the black cat, le chat, or in black film, film.

speaker: Teacher
text: Noir." Very good. So all we, we saw with this how the describing word, the adjective in French, a describing word like black, noir, usually comes after the word it describes. So we don't say black film, but film black, film noir. We don't say the black cat, but the cat black, le chat noir.

speaker: Teacher
text: How would you say she wants the black mobile? She wants the black portable.

speaker: Student
text: Ah. Elle veut le portable noir.

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. And she wants it, meaning the phone.

speaker: Teacher
text: Elle le veut." And she wants it, and we mean a feminine thing. How would that be?

speaker: Teacher
text: Elle la veut." You want it?

speaker: Teacher
text: If we still mean a feminine thing, tu la veux. Good. So we have "tu" for you, as in "tu veux," no, you want. "Tu dois," you must. But if we say, for example, "I want you," rather than "you want." "I see you," rather than "you see." We have a different word for you. We don't use "tu" anymore, but when it's spelt T-E. So you can tell me how would it sound, T-E?

speaker: Teacher
text: Te." [schwa sound] Good. So when we say you, as in "I see you," "I want you," we use "te." [schwa sound] So how would you say for example, "I have to prepare you?" [schwa sound] This isn't you have to, this is I have to prepare you. So here we use "te." [schwa sound] "I have to prepare you." [schwa sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Je dois te [schwa sound] préparer." You have to prepare yourself. This would mean you have to get ready in French. You have to prepare yourself. And for yourself, you can just use this you, "te," [schwa sound] for yourself also. So, "you have to prepare yourself." "You have to get ready."

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Tu dois te [schwa sound] préparer." "I have to get ready, I have to get ready."

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Je dois me [schwa sound] préparer." So, you reapply it what we saw there, no? "You have to get ready" is "You have to prepare yourself." So of course, "I have to get ready, I have to prepare myself." "Je dois me [schwa sound] préparer." How would you say, "I want to invite you"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Je veux t'inviter." "He wants to invite you?"

speaker: Teacher
text: Il veut t'inviter." "Do you want to invite him? Do you want to invite him?"

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Tu veux l'inviter." L'inviter. So here we have tu, no? Because it's you want, rather than I want you or he wants you. So we used tu. "Tu veux l'inviter?" How would you say relaxation in French? Relaxation. Now, the E of re here doesn't have an accent. It's just a normal E. So how does relaxation sound in French?

speaker: Teacher
text: Relaxation." [schwa R sound] And how would to relax be?

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. Relaxer." [schwa R sound] Relaxer." [schwa R sound] But if you want to say for example, "You have to relax," in French, you will say, "You have to relax yourself. You have to relax yourself. You have to relax you." So how would that be?

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Tu dois te [schwa sound] relaxer." [schwa R sound] And the E on relax, what E is it again?
